home.title: We’re getting married!
home.intro: We are so excited to celebrate our special day with you in beautiful Murcia, Spain! Your presence would mean the world to us.
home.intro2: We cannot wait to celebrate our love surrounded by cherished family and friends from all around the world.

getting.title: Getting to Murcia
getting.paragraph1: Murcia is easily reached from the UK, with regular flights from many airports. The nearest airport is Región de Murcia International (RMU), about 30 minutes from the city. Alicante airport (ALC) is also a great option, about an hour away.
getting.paragraph2: For those travelling from outside of Europe, the easiest route is to fly to Madrid’s Adolfo Suárez Madrid–Barajas Airport; from here, you can get a train or a flight to Murcia.
getting.paragraph3: To check the best combination for you, please have a look at routes on Skyscanner.

rmu.title: Murcia Airport
rmu.getThere: About 30 mins from the city by car, or an hour by public transport.
rmu.text1: The closest airport to Murcia, about 30 minutes away by car.
rmu.text2: From the airport, you can take a taxi or use a car hire service to reach the city center.
rmu.transport1: The airport bus takes 30 minutes to get to the city centre.
rmu.transport2: If taking public transport from RMU, there is a short walk from the airport to the bus stop “La Torrica”. Catch BUS 72 which will take you to the city, it will end at “Glorieta de España Par” in the city centre.
rmu.transport3: From here you can transfer to another bus or taxi to get to your accommodation.

alc.title: Alicante Airport
alc.getThere: Just shy of an hour away from the city by either car or public transport.
alc.text1: About an hour away from Murcia by car.
alc.text2: From Alicante Airport, you can take a bus, train, or taxi to Murcia.
alc.transport1: If taking public transport from ALC, there is a shuttle Bus that can take you to Murcia Bus Station in the city.
alc.transport2: It uses a company called ALSA and can be taken from the airport direct to Murcia. This bus runs every 2 hours.

accommodation.title: accommodation
accommodation.subtitle: our recommended accommodation for your comfort
accommodation.paragraph1: Whether you are getting a hotel or sharing an AirBnb between a few pals, we would recommend staying near the city centre if possible. We will be running a bus to and from the wedding to a centre point in town, so easy access to there will help you find your way back after you have had a few!

taxi.title: taxis
taxi.text1: Taxis and Ubers are available in Murcia, although Uber is not that popular in the city, so availability might be more limited.
taxi.text2: Taxis can be booked on the Pidetaxi app.

carhire.title: car hire
carhire.text1: If you’re planning to explore beyond Murcia, hiring a car is the easiest way.
carhire.text2: Please see the airports section for links of different car rental options.

walking.title: walking
walking.text1: Murcia is a safe and very walkable city, so you might want to explore the city by foot.

public.title: public transport
public.text1: It’s very good if you need to get to the other side of the city, but get your Spanish prepped, as the drivers may not speak your lingo!
public.text2: If you need to go outside the city, public transport is less frequent and not quite as good.

weather.title: weather
weather.subtitle: quick climate guide so you can come prepared
weather.text1: Late May in Murcia is the turning point from spring into full blown Summer. Expect it to be warm!
weather.text2: For the days, bring your SPF and light clothes for your off days and enjoy basking in the Sun!
weather.text3: Evenings may be slightly cooler, so do bring something long sleeved, but you can leave your woolly jumpers at home!

language.title: language
language.text1: Spanish people love when you speak their language, even if it is just a few words. Below are some useful phrases to get around:
language.text2:
Hola = Hello
Por favor = Please
Gracias = Thank you
¿Dónde está…? = Where is…
El Baño = The bathroom
¿La cuenta, por favor? = The bill, please
Una cerveza, por favor = A beer, please

food.title: food & drink
food.text1: Lunch is eaten around 14:00-15:00 and it is the main meal in Spain. This is why shops often close for a few hours in the afternoon. It is not because everyone is having a siesta, but so that people can go home to have lunch with their family! Shops open until 21:00-22:00, at which point is time to have dinner.  Restaurants will often not open for dinner before 20:00, so please be flexible with your eating times.
food.text2: Tapas Culture: Tapas are meant to be shared, so don’t be shy about ordering a mix for the table.

general.title: general tips
general.text1: Greetings: A friendly “hola” (hello) or “buenos días” (good morning) goes a long way.
general.text2: Kisses on the Cheek: It’s common to greet with two kisses (one on each cheek), even if you’ve just met.
general.text3: Tipping: Not as expected as in the UK. Rounding up the bill or leaving a euro or two for good service is plenty.
general.text4: Don’t Rush: Service is more relaxed, and there is usually no limit on how long you can stay at your table. If you need the bill, ask for it (“la cuenta, por favor”) — it won’t just appear.
general.text5: Cash vs Card: Cards are widely accepted, but it’s handy to have some euros for taxis, buses, small bars, and markets.
general.text6: Sundays: Don’t expect too much to go on this day. Shops may be closed, but restaurants / bars should be open.

faqs.title: FAQs
faqs.subtitle: you have questions, we have answers

q1.question: Where can I confirm my attendance?
q1.answer: All RSVPs are done online (scroll up a bit and click the big RSVP button), but if you have trouble with the form, please contact Alex or Maria.

q2.question: What date should I RSVP by?

q3.question: Can I bring a plus one?
q3.answer: We have set up the RSVP so that one person per party can fill it in. In order to keep our wedding personal and intimate, invitations are extended to established couples only, so we can celebrate our special day with those we know and love.

q4.question: Can small children come?
q4.answer: We love your little ones, but our wedding will be for adults and teenagers only. We kindly ask that young children not attend, partly due to venue rules and partly so that everyone can eat, drink, and dance without worrying about nap times.

q5.question: Dress code & outfit tips
q5.answer: We kindly ask guests to dress in semi-formal attire. Suits and ties, dresses and generally elegant outfits are encouraged. It’s not a black-tie event, so no need for tuxedos or floor-length gowns — but we’d love everyone to feel dressed up for the occasion. Please refrain from wearing white or white-adjacent colours. Since the celebration will be outdoors in the Spanish sunshine, lighter fabrics and bright colours are encouraged. If choosing to wear heels, you may wish to choose wedges or block heels instead of stilettos.

q6.question: Where will the bus depart from to go to the venue?
q6.answer: The bus will depart from/ return to Hotel Siete Coronas. We will confirm the departure time closer to the date
